sp.speaker: Riv.
sp.l: This was not wont.

sp.speaker: Alo.
sp.l: We dare not sir dispute
Our masters pleasure.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Perhaps his confessor is with him.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Perhaps there is some cunning; nay prefer
The business of the soul, I may presume
He has no long Catalogue to account for.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: You have not been of counsel with his conscience,
We do not use to limit his devotions.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: It is pious, and you three by computation
Montaltoes knaves here placed, to keep away
Discoveries: in spite of all your subtleties,
The king shall know my mind, and understand
The history of your patrons and your service;
Let time speak your reward in your own chronicles.

sp.speaker: Alo.
sp.l: You not forget my Lord Montalto has
Desire to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: It is all my business;
Be careful of your watch and look about you,
Some Weasel may get in else.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Does he jeer us?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Let him; his Embassy is not performed.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You do amaze my understanding Sir
To require I should justify a tale
Made to the blemish of so chaste a Lady.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Did not your Lordship tell such a story,
To Philoberto in my lodgings.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I dare his malice to affirm it; and it is not
Done like yourself to sully with one breath
Two fames.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Shall I not credit my own ears?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Dear Sir, collect yourself, and let not passion
To Domitilla whom you may possess,
Hereafter make you so unjust.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Dear Machiavill
This will not do; the King shall know your stratagems.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Go threaten babes; this would exalt my rage,
But I remember you are a guest to Naples,
Nor would I grieve the genius of my country,
To place my own revenge above her honour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Poor shadow.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Now.

div1.stage: Drawes a dagger at the Dukes barke.

sp.l: It will not be safe; you know your charge.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: We are proud to see your excellence in health.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Where is the King?

sp.speaker: Alo.
sp.l: A little busy Sir.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Not yet I think, he is at his prayers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I will add to his Litany.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: It would not need;
I think his ghostly father can direct him,
With whom he is in private.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I know not
How to interpret this; I want Philoberto .

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Your graces
Servant; he looks displeased.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: My Lord Octavio .

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Your servant Lords.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: You meet the Duke.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: His face showed discontent.

sp.speaker: Aloi.
sp.l: We sum our fortunes in Montaltoes smile,
By whose commands we have denied the Duke
Access to the King.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: You have done well; it much
Concerns my Lord; his and all our fate
Depends upon it; continue still your care
And circumspection, and while I am within
Let none be admitted.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Let us alone;
A spirit may have the device to enter,
But if he have so much body as a Gnat
I will know his errand; who is this; O it it is
My Lady Domitillaes Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: Here are so many tricks, and turns, and doors
In these Court lodgings, I have lost myself.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Master . Secretary.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: It was you betrayed me to the King, and caused
My Ladies to be sent for, with more cunning
To bring me hither; but all is one, he has
Not seen me yet nor shall not; which
Is my way out of this labyrinth?

sp.speaker: Alo.
sp.l: Why are you so unwilling the King should see you?

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Or to live in Court; methinks this habit
Becomes you now; does it not my Lord.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: He looks like a true Hero.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: You are beside the story Sir; I did read once
That Hero had no upper lip; she was
A Lady of Leanders lake.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: A wit? there is a new word; now for the Hellespont,
He will make a subtle courtier.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: It has undone me.

sp.speaker: Alo.
sp.l: Undone thee how?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: I know not whether it be my wit or clothes,
Or disposition of the place, or all
Together, but I am sure I am in love,
I find it by the losing of my stomach;
I am most strangely in love.

sp.speaker: Guid
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Aloi.
sp.l: Can you not guess.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: I hope it is with myself, for I did vow
When my first mistress dyed which was.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: A dairy maid that we had in the Country,
To love no living woman above an hour;
she was the very cream of all her Sex;
Oft have we churned together.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: And drunk healths
In Buttermilk.

sp.speaker: Aloi.
sp.l: But do you hope you are in love with yourself Sir.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: Marry do I Sir; is that so wonderful at Court.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: You are pleasant.

sp.speaker: Aloi.
sp.l: Let us be rid on him.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Come you shall now speak with the King,
And he shall knight thee; more honours may follow.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: You shall excuse me; put your honours
Upon somebody else.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Do you know what it is.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: I have not read of late.

sp.speaker: Aloi.
sp.l: But you are much given to hearing,
What is honour.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: Honour a bubble is that is soon broke,
A Glowworm seeming fire, but has no smoke.

sp.speaker: Aloi.
sp.l: There is fire and water.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: And smoke for air;
A painted Sunbeam, piece of gilded Chaff,
And he that trusts leans to a broken staff.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: You should have reconciled the four elements
To the conceit; there was fire, air, water;
Where is the earth.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: O he that leans to a broken staff shall
Find that presently.

div1.stage: Enter King reading a paper, Octavio.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: The King.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.l: King by your leave; I vanish.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This paper contains wonder; it is not possible.

sp.speaker: Octa.
sp.l: Upon my life Sir, Philoberto can demonstrate these.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The Devil has not art
To abuse us so; this will require some counsel;
He is here,
Montalto; leave us.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir your pleasure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is all in thee; hast met with Philoberto?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No matter; I have thought upon it,
And do conclude it best to let things pass
Yet in a dream; choice and enquiry may.
Awake suspicion upon innocence.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You cannot think her guilty Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am not
Without some fears; I have collected things
Since we conferred, that stagger my good thoughts.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Of her you cannot; Sir untying again,
Whatever would betray her to your jealousy;
A Virgin's Monument cannot be more chaste
In the Temple.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Yes, yes; we may be all cozened;
And therefore let her pass among things desperate;
Yet were I certain she were spotted thus,
As it is but a young Leprosy upon her,
I could wish heartily my Sister timely
Married, not to the Duke that would betray us,
But to someone I know not, who could love
Us both, so well as be that rare friend
And save our honours.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: do you then suspect her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: O the Dukes Character had a powerful sense;
And who knows but she may be lost by one
Not fit to make her reparation;
Could any Nobleman be found in Naples
To bind her wound up by so great an act
Of secrecy and marriage; but some wind
May listen and convey, I know not whether,
What my sad breath has scattered in the air;
Thy Master has no servant that dares take
One sorrow from him.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You are Sir provided
Of more than that can rise to in my service.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Canst thou be so compassionate to lose
Thy hopes of richer beauty, for my sake?
Darest thou with all this knowledge hide her stain,
And marry her?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: My duty to your Majesty
Shall marry me to death; let not this trouble
The quiet of your heart; I will take Theodosia,
And think upon her as she had the whiteness
Of my good Angel.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Thou art a miracle;
Teach me but which way I may reward this love;
Till now I had no poverty; thy worth
Will make me everlastingly in debt;
What shall I say?

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Great Sir, no more; your favours
Flow from a bounty, which hath only heaven
Above it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: They are all trifles; let me see,
Is nothing in thy power to make thee find
My gratitude? how barren are we, wealth,
Honour.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: There is nothing good or great you have not
Freely possessed me with; your favours would,
So mighty have they fallen upon me, rather
Express a storm, and I had sunk beneath
The welcome violence, had not your love
From whence they flowed, enabled me to strength
And manly bearing.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I was improvident
To reserve nothing, or it was a fault
In thee to be so prodigal of merit
In thy past services; canst thou think of nothing
Worth my addition.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Nothing Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I have it,
And thank my better genius I have it,
Such a reward Montalto that I dare
Be modest yet pronounce, never did Prince
Exceed it to his friend.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Sir you amaze me,
And shame my want of merit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In the title,
Let Kings peruse the benefit and study
An imitation to their best loved creatures;
They are great as fortune can invent; I will teach thee
A way Montalto, to know all thy friends
And enemies.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: That were a precious knowledge,
Were it in nature; with your highness pardon
The hearts of men are not to be measured
With what we reach the stars, or fathom Seas;
O he that is active in a state has more
Chained to him by the power and strength of office,
Than genuine respect; and it is not worth
Or person, but the fortunes of a Statesman
That sometimes men adore.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is true; and therefore
I am proud in this that I can teach thee look
Into men's souls, to know them fit for scorn, or
Thy embraces.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: How may this Sir be done?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Almost in the twinkling of an eye too.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Strange.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I seem to frown upon thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Dost apprehend me; I will counterfeit
That I am displeased with thee; do not mistake me,
And have it voiced about the Court, thou art
Confined, dost mark; at this will all thy enemies
Whose hearts thou canst not see, their tongues before
By thy great power silenced, join in faction
Complain, discover their whole stock of malice,
Tickling their spleens, that thou art out of favour,
Whom I shall hear and smile at; then all those
Whose honest souls deserve thee, will rise up,
The champions of thy fame on the other side
And be so many Orators to make
Thy faith and honour slain; when this done,
The scene is changed, I send for thee; thou comest
With a most glorious train; and then I will smile,
Take thee again in the sight of all, discover
It was but a trick, thy friends keep still thy bosom,
And thou in triumph shootest a scorn with mine
To strike all envy dumb; Is it not a rare one?
I cannot do enough for thee Montalto .

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You have found out a way I must confess;
But with your pardon, I shall be more able
To do you service in the other ignorance,
Than run a desperate hazard in this knowledge;
Some hold it sin, and capital enough
To have the Princes favour, which once lost
Though but in suspicion; they may rage,
And like a torrent rise to overwhelm nature.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: These shall not wound thee.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: And how other Judges
May wrest the actions of a man employed
Though never so faithful to his King and state.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I am confident of thy justice and decree,
Thy triumph in it; thy goodness thus conspicuous
Renders thee loved, and fit for Theodosia
When she is brightest; the Sun never smiles
More cheerful upon teeming earth,
Than I to find thee perfect; for I do
But seem displeased; come, I will have it so;
If thou dost love me, no dispute, but let me
Pursue my fancy meant to do thee honour.
Who waits?
Now it begins;
Attend my Lord Montalto to his Chamber,
Where our will is, he be confined until
Our pleasure further known.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Aloigio Confined!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No ceremony Sir; when that is done,
We ease you of the trouble too of waiting;
You know the way my Lords to your own lodgings,
From whence on peril of our anger stir not
Until we send for you--- Octavio .

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Do we not dream.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Something would creep
Like a dead sleep upon me; I am in
A Labyrinth; but hence with coward fear;
I know the worst; grim death can but translate
Me hence, and there is an end of death and fate.

div1.stage:
The fift Act.
The fift Act.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: He consorted and counselled Domitilla;
I have my part in loves affliction.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: This I feared
I must acquaint the King; where is your fellow
Bombo? his mirth might now be seasonable.

sp.speaker: Iaca.
sp.l: He is gone Madam.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Gone, whither?

sp.speaker: Iaca.
sp.l: Back to the country house; he heard of my Lord
Montaltoes disgrace, and the fear of his supplying
The place of a favourite, sent him away this morning
With all his movables; the country he says
Is wholesome, where he will die without fear or wit when
His time comes; he durst not stay to see the King.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Would we had still been strangers to the Court;
Leave us; my daughter is much bound to your grace.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: It is the King you speak of; pray be careful
You speak all goodness of him, he deserves it,
And will when I am dead.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I will lose no time.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I wish it prosper.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: I dare not say the King dissembles with me;
That were a fault beyond my love; but sure
Something he said that made my heart believe
He did not mean me for another; and
Montalto, whose reward I must be thought,
Is now confined, and under his displeasure.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: He will have more care of his honour then
To place thee so unworthily; Montalto
Has played the cunning traitor with our loves,
If I may trust thee noble Philoberto
That told me the whole story of his falsehood,
Which I before suspected.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: And if he should despise me as it is justice,
Will heaven be angry if I love him still;
Or will the King call it a treason in me?
If he do, I can willingly die for it,
And with my last words pray he may live happy;
But why am I this trouble to your grace?
My story is not worth one of your minutes;
Dear Madam pardon me, and teach me how
To make my time more happy, spent in something
That may concern your highness; you do love too.

sp.speaker: Iaca.
sp.l: Madam, the Duke of Florence .

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: How the Duke?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Why does he visit me? Madam indeed
You may believe I love him not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Admit him
Aye prithee, and conceal me Domitilla;
I know he comes a-wooing to thy beauty;
I prithee let me hear the second part:

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: I shall against my own desires obey you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The ambition of my eyes cannot be thought
Immodest, if they ever wish to dwell here;
They have found their light again; let no misfortune
Be a second cause to bury me in darkness.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Your graces pardon, if my haste to attend
The King and his commands made me appear
Rude when I left your excellence.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: This does more
Than satisfy.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: I know not how I may
Stand guilty in your thoughts by keeping a
Rich Caskanet.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You honoured me to accept it.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: But with a blush I must remember too
I did not thank you; there was want of time
Or manners; I must leave it to your mercy,
And would by any duty to your grace
Expiate my error.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Madam it is not worth
The mention of this gratitude; Your breath
Makes the oblation rich, and me who am
Encouraged by your vertue, to present you
With something of more value, than a world
Of these poor empty glories; I dare give you
My heart Madam.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Bless your grace from such a meaning.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Can you be cruel to it?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: I never had
The confidence to look upon a wound;
And such a bleeding object as your heart
Would fright my senses.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You are more ingenious
Than not to understand that I mean love;
I love you Madam, best of all your sex.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: You cannot Sir, you dare not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: You dare not be so wicked I am am sure
When you remember, what you are, a Prince.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Is it a sin for Princes to love Madam?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Or if you could dispense with so much passion
To love me, and durst give me, what I tremble
To think you promise, that, that very act
In which you most advance affection to me,
Would make me think you love me not.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be clearer.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: How should I think his courtship worth my trust,
And meet him with a real change of hearts,
Who in his very first attempt of love,
Would blast my honour, and betray me to
A shame, black as the tongue of infamy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Would I?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: And more;
For you in this
Would tempt me to an act, by which I should
Not only wound myself to death of honour,
But make me guilty of another's blood,
And kill an innocent Lady, whose least tear
Is worth a thousand lives of perjured men
That make a scorn of vertue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: What Lady?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Have you forgot the Princess Sir?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The Princess!

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: In that name you will find yourself again
Lost in a mist of passions; O think
The fames and hopes of two rich countries are
Engaged upon your faith; your highness pardon.
I find some blushes chide my too much boldness,
And by a nearer view now of your goodness,
I see my error to believe you meant
Other than trial of me, or could fall
To any thought beneath your birth and honour.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But if Theodosia be made another's
Justice may I be thought then to address
My passions hither.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: If the Princess, which
I must not think, give your heart back again,
And that you could quit all your ties with honour,
My thoughts are all resigned to the King's will;
He must dispose of me, by my own vow,
Without his free consent never to marry.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: The King; there it is; I thought she was his mistress;
It is not possible the Princess now
Can pardon my neglect; Montaltoes practise
Upon me, and his poisoning of her vertue
Would not excuse my shame; I dare not see
Whom I have injured, Theodosia;
I am resolved, this night I will steal from Naples .

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Nay do not hide your face my Lord; it will
Appear as fresh and lovely to my eyes,
As when it first presented me your smiles;
I am Theodosia still.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: But I have been:

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Abused; time will discover to the ruin
Of his own name, and glory of our loves,
Montaltoes practise to divide our souls.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: You cannot be so merciful; or else
This sweetness is put on to enlarge my guilt,
When we are both compared; dare you believe
I can repent and be revenged.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Upon whom?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Upon myself, for suffering my eyes
To wander from this sweetness.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: You outdo
The satisfaction; if your grace can find
Me grow again within your heart, where first
My love desired to plant.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: O let me drown
My blushes in this overflow of charity;
But there is an act that justice calls me to,
Before I can be worthy of this peace.
Montalto has played the villain; now I find it,
And from his treacherous heart my sword must force
A bloody satisfaction for thy honour,
Poisoned by him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Stay that revenge; shame has
Already sunk him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.l: Sir the King desires
Some conference with your grace, and with you Madam.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I shall attend you Sir; we shall present
Together, thus no object to displease him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Though I shall blush to see him, I will wait on you.

div1.stage:
Exeunt.
Enter King, Riviero, Andrugio; Petitioners.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Good heaven, upon what human bosom shall
We that are made your substitutes on earth
Place secure confidence? and yet there may
Be malice in complaints; the flourishing Oak
For his extent of Branches, stature, growth,
The darling and the Idol of the wood,
Whose awful nod the under trees adore,
Shook by a tempest, and thrown down must need
Submit his curled head and full grown limbs,
To every common Axe, be patient, while
The tortures put to every joint the Saws
And engines, making with their very noise
The Forests groan and tremble; but not one
When it was in his strength and state reviled it,
Whom poverty of soul, and envy sends
To gather sticks from the trees wished for ruin,
The great man's Emblem; I did love Montalto,
And would not have him lost if justice would
Consent, and be a little of his side;
But here are the two plummets weigh him down;
His impious practice on the Duke, and base
Aspersions on our sister that defame
Our whole blood, is a loud, loud accusation.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: His conscience dares not Sir deny it.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And you
Speak here the tragic story of Riviero,
Whose honest soul for not complying with
His power and ends, chose in a discontent
To make himself an exile, you pursued,
And by the practise of Montalto poisoned
At Rome.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: This letter sent to Alvarez,
Whose treacherous Physic purged his soul away,
Is too much testimony.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is his Character.
Octavio you come for justice too.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: It were a vain breath to desire it Sir;
Your thoughts are still so conscious of vertue,
They will prevent petition.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come nearer.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: The King is troubled.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Where he loved, to find
So much ingratitude.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Andrugio.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Things are not yet mature for my discovery.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You observe---away---
We may be just Philoberto,
Yet not destroy another attribute,
Which shows whose representative we are;
Mercy becomes a King; too much can be
But thought a sin on the right hand; we are
Resolved.
Madam you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: I begin
To fear there is some spell upon the King;
If after this Montalto shall prevail,
Let innocence be stronger to the world,
And heaven be afraid to punish vice.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Remove
For a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: I obey.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You tell me wonders Madam; alas poor Lady,
I shall then have enough to reconcile;
She was too hasty to interpret me
Her lover.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: If you Sir apply no cure,
The fond impression may I fear endanger
Her sense and life; I urged Montalto Sir
By your command, before his change of fortune,
But she took no delight to hear him named.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No, no, nor I; good heaven how I am troubled
How to repair this pretty piece of innocence,
Whom I have brought into a waking dream
Of passion; something I must do; pray tell me,
But tell me truth; I charge thee by thy duty
To me, to Naples, and to heaven, or if
There be in woman's faith, or thy Religion
Anything else to make it up a full
And perfect conjuration.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: You fright me;
Without these not a thought within my heart
But you have power to summon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Tell me then,
Is Domitilla virtuous?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Is she exceeding virtuous; is she most
Divinely chaste; can she do more than blush
At wanton sounds; will she be very angry
At an immodest offer, and be frighted
To hear it named; tell me; does she pray
And weep, and would be torn upon the rack
Ere she consent to stain one virgin thought?
Or dares she more than Lucrece kill herself
To save her honour, or do something more
Miraculously than all this to preserve
Her white name to posterity.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I know not
How to reply to these particulars;
But if your meaning be to have me speak
Truth of her modest and pure thoughts, she is
All that her mother can beseech of heaven
To bless a child with of so chaste a soul,
And virtuous simplicity.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: No more;
I do believe, and will find out a way
To make her satisfaction; it is just;
Say I desire her presence.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: Now you bless us;
A widow's prayers and tears for this great bounty.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Your sister and the Duke Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is new trouble.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Never so lovingly united;
The pleasant language of their eyes and gestures
Doth speak their hearts at peace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: That would rejoice me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Take us to your love;
All jealousies are banished, and we both
Breath from one soul.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My wonder and my joy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Your pardon.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take my bosom.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The misfortune
Kept us at distance, was your creatures act.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: The clouds are now removed.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Lord Montalto, Sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let Music speak
His dear approach; we sent for him.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let me entreat you to obscure your persons
A while.

div1.stage:
Exit Duke, Theodosia.
Loud Musicke---Enter Guido, Aloisio, Alexio, Andrugio, Octavio, Montalto.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My Lord you are welcome to us, very welcome
We have kept our word, and find you have not lost
Your confidence; what a brave armour is
An innocent soul? How like a rock it bids
Defiance to a storm, against whose ribs
The insolent waves, but dash themselves in pieces,
And fall and hide their heads in passionate foam;
How would a guilty person tremble now,
Look pale, and with his eyes chained to the ground:
Betray his fear of justice.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Where should honour
Shine with his pure and native lustre but
Where there is such a King, so good, so great,
The example and reward, he must be
A rebel twice to vertue that can live
To be convinced of a dishonour near
Such an instructive goodness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where be all his fierce accusers?
Call them to his presence,
Whom all their envies would destroy.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: So, so;
The King is charmed.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: They are gone upon the first
News of my Lords return; they vanished Sir.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: So may all treason fly the brow of innocence

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is well said; but they shall not fly their names;
Read there just to our thoughts, they apprehended
Thee lost in our displeasure (wheres our sister)
And now they came to be revenged Montalto,
Upon our favours.

sp.speaker: Guid.
sp.l: Right, and please your grace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is something may concern your want of grace Andrugio, Philoberto .

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: We are undone Guido, and I see more
Engines are leveled at my fate.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: The King would have your Lordship peruse this.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And these.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: That you may know your friends and enemies.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: Lost, lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Sir you know
You have obliged the Princess Theodosia
And the Duke to you, and you may presume
To use their favours, they are here.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: It were better
For me they had no being. I did never
Expect this; to accuse me for the death
Of Riviero; but I must obey
This fatal revolution.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why does Montalto kneel.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: I dare not ask your pardon,
Only I beg you would put on a brow
Rough as the cause you have to make it frown,
And that may strike me dead without more torment.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Ingrateful man! am I rewarded thus;
Not only with my faith abused and subjects,
But wounding all our honours.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Let him find your mercy Sir
For his offence to me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I must not, dare not pardon; it were a sin
In me of violence to heaven and justice.

sp.speaker: Mont.
sp.l: You have been a Royal Master.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Take him hence;
His life will draw a scorn upon the Kingdom;
Expect the censure of our laws you gentlemen
We only banish from the court.

sp.speaker: Gui. Aloi. Alex.
sp.l: You are merciful.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Pray and be honest.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: That last will be the greatest penance to them.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My passion would be strong but here is one
Come to divert the stream; how is it with
My pretty Domitilla; you and I
May change some words in private.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: The King is just, and it is within your silence
To make Montalto nothing.

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: Apace without that weight upon him; malice
Shall have no share in my revenge.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And since Montalto
Is become incapable,
I would not marry thee; that is a thing too common,
But thou shalt be my mistress, a preferment
Above my first intention; be wise
And entertain it; O the days and nights
We will spend together.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: The King is very pleasant
With Domitilla.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come kiss me
Domitilla; kiss me now
Before all these; what needs this modesty;
Come let us take in one another's soul.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Are you the King of Naples.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So they call me,
And if there be a power within that name
It shall be thine to make thee glorious,
And great above our Queen; there is no title
Like unto that our heat and blood creates
A mistress Domitilla.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Are you Sir in earnest?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Do but thou consent, and I
Will give thee such a proof in my embraces
Of the delight; they will not follow us;
I will tell thee more in the bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: I dare
Not understand this language; can the King
Be impious; how was my opinion cozened
Sin hath deformed his very shape; his voice
Hath now no harmony.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: This is but to draw
More courtship from me.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Pardon I beseech you;
I have found my error.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Will she yield?

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: I did consent
Too soon to my captivity,
Though modesty would not allow me strength
To tell you so; but you have Sir, by what
My fond thoughts never did expect, relieved me,
to make me know myself; and now preserving
That duty which I owe you as my King,
I call love back again, and can look on
Your lusts with a becoming scorn.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You can.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Yes, and were Naples, Rome, and all the wealth
Of Italy laid down, the great temptation,
Thus I would spurn their glories.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come this is but the trick of all your sex;
We know you can dissemble appetite,
As if you were not flesh and blood.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Sir give
Me leave to go while I have power to pray for you,
Where was I lost? is there no friend to goodness;
Have I contracted such a leprous form
That I have lost all men's defence and charity.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Madam your innocence doth raise in me,
Though young, a willing champion, and with
My safe obedience to the King, I dare,
Armed with the witness of her cause, defy
The greatest soldier in the world.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Sir, in a noble cause, if you to whom
In the first place truth flies as to an Altar,
Wave her religious defence, I dare die for her.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You so brave? to prison with him;
We will correct your sauciness.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: You will grace
My first act Sir, and get me fame by suffering
For so much sweetness.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: Let not your displeasure
Great Sir fall upon him; revenge what you
Call disobedience here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You owe much to
His confidence; nor is there any punishment
Beyond your love and liking of his boldness;
You two should make a marriage with your follies.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Let Domitilla make Octavio
So blest.

sp.speaker: Dom.
sp.l: My Lord you now deserve I should
Be yours, whom with the hazard of the King's
Anger, and your own life you have defended;
There is a spring of honour here, and to it
In the presence of the King, his Court and Heaven,
I dare now give my heart; nor is it without
My duty to a promise.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: Now you make
Octavio happy.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: It is to my desires,
And I dare wish you joys; forgive this practise;
Nay pretty Domitilla I did this
But to divert more happily thy thoughts
Of me, who have not paid yet the full tribute
To my Cesarias dust; again let me
Congratulate thy choice in young Octavio,
Whose birth and forward vertue will deserve thee;
Brother and sister love, and wish them happiness.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: May all joys spring within their hearts.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: I must present this gentleman to be more known to you.

sp.speaker: Octav.
sp.l: I hope you are no enemy to this blessing.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.l: I add what doth become a most glad mother,
A blessing to your loves.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Noble Riviero .

sp.speaker: Rivi.
sp.l: I live again by your acknowledgment.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Sir you may trust my testimony; Alvarez
Letter is now an argument of his safety,
Who is yet living to increase the guilt
Of false Montalto .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Welcome; it is thy life
That hath reversed Montaltoes doom, whose sentence
Now shall be only banishment; our hearts
Are full and sprightly; nothing wants but to
Perfect with holy ceremony, what
Your hearts have sealed; mirth in each bosom flows,
Distraction never had so sweet a close.

div1.stage:
Back matter
THE EPILOGVE. As it vvas spoken to the Lord Deputie on Newyeares-day at night, by way of vote, congratulating the New yeare.

sp.l: Our Poet doth forget his Play;
There is something he would pay
Due to your greatness, and the day
Which by a revolution of the sphere
Is proud to open the New year.
And having looked on you, hath hid his face,
And Changed his robe with Stars to grace
And light you going to bed, so wait
With trembling Lustre on your state.
Shine brighter yet, you are not the same
Clear Lamps you were shine like the name
Of him I bow too, while aflame
Active, and burning here with pure desires
Shall equal the best borrowed fires.
May health, the bosom's friend, stream through your blood,
And know no ebb of the chaste flood,
And though time shift, and years renew,
May yet the Spring be still in you.
May She, whom heaven hath sweetly graced
And in your noble bosom placed,
Whose heart by only yours embraced,
Hath made one true, and holy Gordian, prove
Fruitful in Children, as in love.
And may this fair Top-branch, whose early bloom
Doth promise all the fruit can come
To vertue, and your name be blest,
And live a story to the rest.
All Honour with your fame increase,
In your bosom dwell soft peace,
And Justice, the true root of these;
Wealth be the worst, and outside of your fate;
And may not heaven your life translate,
Till for your Royal Master, and this Isle,
Your deeds have filled a Chronicle;
In all that is great, and good, be bold,
And every year be copy of the old.
